Call of Duty franchise.search_query: When was the first Call of Duty game released?
Call of Duty franchise.evidence:
The first *Call of Duty* game was released on October 29, 2003, for Microsoft Windows. Developed by Infinity Ward and published by Activision, it is a first-person shooter that simulates infantry and combined arms warfare during World War II. The game is notable for presenting multiple viewpoints across the American, British, and Soviet campaigns in Europe. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty_%28video_game%29?utm_source=openai))

Since its debut, the *Call of Duty* franchise has expanded significantly, with numerous sequels and spin-offs. The most recent installment, *Call of Duty: Black Ops 7*, was released on November 14, 2025. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty%3A_Black_Ops_7?utm_source=openai))

For a visual overview of the game's evolution, you might find this trailer for *Call of Duty: Modern Warfare* insightful:

[Call of Duty: Modern Warfare | Official Multiplayer Open Beta Release Date Trailer](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=peZdl_VunoA&utm_source=openai)

Introduction of bullet drop in Call of D.search_query: When was bullet drop introduced in Call of Duty?
Introduction of bullet drop in Call of D.evidence:
Bullet drop was first introduced in the Call of Duty series with the release of *Call of Duty: Black Ops 4* in 2018. Treyarch, the game's developer, implemented a new ballistics system that incorporated bullet drop, allowing players to experience more realistic long-range engagements. This feature was initially tested during the game's multiplayer beta in August 2018. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/treyarch-dev-reveals-bullet-drop-and-new-ballistics-system-will-be-tested-in-black-ops-4-multiplayer-beta-129626/?utm_source=openai))

In *Call of Duty: Modern Warfare* (2019), Infinity Ward expanded on this concept by introducing bullet drop and windage mechanics in the campaign mode. Art director Joel Emslie explained that players would need to account for bullet drop and, in some cases, wind direction when using designated marksman rifles (DMRs) or sniper rifles. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/call-of-duty-dev-reveals-how-bullet-drop-will-work-modern-warfare-710625/?utm_source=openai))

The introduction of bullet drop in these titles marked a significant shift from the previous "hitscan" mechanics, where bullets would instantly hit their target without any travel time or drop. This change added a layer of realism and strategy, especially in long-range combat scenarios.

For a visual explanation of how bullet drop works in *Call of Duty: Warzone*, you might find this video helpful:

[ULTIMATE Sniper Bullet Velocity and Bullet Drop Guide for Call Of Duty Warzone!](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4hRm1CBhweM&utm_source=openai)

Bullet drop was not a standard mechanic in the franchise's hitscan-based multiplayer for many years; it became a defining feature with the release of Blackout (2018) and the massively popular Call of Duty: Warzone (2020).

Call of Duty: Warzone.search_query: When was Call of Duty: Warzone released?
Call of Duty: Warzone.evidence:
Call of Duty: Warzone was initially released on March 10, 2020, as a free-to-play battle royale game for PlayStation 4, Windows, and Xbox One. It was developed by Raven Software and Infinity Ward, and published by Activision. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty%3A_Warzone?utm_source=openai))

A successor, initially titled Call of Duty: Warzone 2.0, was released on November 16, 2022. This version introduced a new map and additional features, and was later renamed simply Call of Duty: Warzone. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty%3A_Warzone_%282022_video_game%29?utm_source=openai))

A mobile adaptation, Call of Duty: Warzone Mobile, was launched on March 21, 2024. However, Activision announced in May 2025 that the game would be removed from app stores and discontinued due to not meeting expectations. ([windowscentral.com](https://www.windowscentral.com/gaming/this-call-of-duty-game-is-being-taken-down-after-just-one-year-get-it-now-before-its-gone?utm_source=openai))

As of January 2026, Call of Duty: Warzone continues to receive updates and new content, including the recent integration with Black Ops 7 in December 2025. ([pcgamer.com](https://www.pcgamer.com/games/call-of-duty/black-ops-7-season-1-release-date-roadmap-warzone/?utm_source=openai))

Introduction of bullet drop in Call of D.search_query: When was bullet drop introduced in Call of Duty multiplayer or Blackout?
Introduction of bullet drop in Call of D.evidence:
Bullet drop was introduced in Call of Duty's Blackout mode, the battle royale component of Black Ops 4, during its beta phase in August 2018. Treyarch developer Tony Flame revealed that the studio would be implementing a new 'ballistics system,' including bullet drop, in the Black Ops 4 Beta. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/treyarch-dev-reveals-bullet-drop-and-new-ballistics-system-will-be-tested-in-black-ops-4-multiplayer-beta-129626/?utm_source=openai))

In Blackout, bullets act as projectiles with travel time and drop-off, requiring players to compensate for these factors, especially at longer ranges. This mechanic was a significant departure from the traditional hitscan system used in previous Call of Duty multiplayer modes, where bullets hit targets instantly without travel time. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/how-bullet-drop-works-call-duty-blackout-190359/?utm_source=openai))

While bullet drop was initially tested in Blackout, Treyarch also considered implementing it in the traditional multiplayer mode. However, after testing during the Black Ops 4 Beta, the feature was not included in the final release of the multiplayer mode. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/karma-and-parasite-react-to-bullet-drop-being-added-to-the-black-ops-4-beta-129714/?utm_source=openai))

Therefore, bullet drop was introduced in Call of Duty's Blackout mode during the Black Ops 4 Beta in August 2018 but was not implemented in the standard multiplayer mode.

The original *Fate/stay night* visual novel was released in Japan on January 30, 2004, for Windows PCs. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fate/stay_night?utm_source=openai)) This marked the first commercial release by Type-Moon, following their earlier work on *Tsukihime*.

The game was later ported to various platforms, including PlayStation Vita in 2012, and mobile devices in 2015. sample_3.justification: The question and answer explicitly reference VB.NET 2008 and the DataGridView control. Visual Studio 2008 (which includes VB.NET 2008) was released in late 2007, and the DataGridView control was introduced in .NET 2.0 in 2005.

VB.NET 2008.evidence:
Visual Basic 2008 (VB 9.0) was released alongside the .NET Framework 3.5 on November 19, 2007. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_Basic_%28.NET%29?utm_source=openai)) This release introduced several new features, including:

- A true conditional operator, "If(condition as Boolean, truepart, falsepart)", to replace the "IIf" function.
- Anonymous types.
- Support for Language Integrated Query (LINQ).
- Lambda expressions.
- XML literals.
- Type inference.
- Extension methods.

These enhancements aimed to improve the language's expressiveness and developer productivity.

DataGridView control.search_query: When was the DataGridView control introduced in .NET?

VB.NET 2008.evidence:
Visual Basic 2008 (VB 9.0) was released alongside the .NET Framework 3.5 on November 19, 2007. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_Basic_%28.NET%29?utm_source=openai)) This release introduced several new features, including:

- Anonymous types.
- Support for Language Integrated Query (LINQ).
- Lambda expressions.
- XML literals.
- Type inference.
- Extension methods.

These enhancements aimed to improve the language's expressiveness and developer productivity.

SelectionBoxItemStringFormat property.search_query: When was the ComboBox.SelectionBoxItemStringFormat property added to WPF?
SelectionBoxItemStringFormat property.evidence:
The `ComboBox.SelectionBoxItemStringFormat` property was introduced in .NET Framework 4.5, which was released in October 2012. This property allows you to specify a format string for the selected item in a `ComboBox`, providing greater control over how the selected item is displayed.

Prior to this, developers had to use workarounds, such as setting the `ItemStringFormat` property or applying a `DataTemplate` to the `ComboBox` to achieve similar formatting effects. For example, a Stack Overflow discussion from May 2011 highlights challenges with setting the `ItemStringFormat` property and suggests using a `DataTemplate` to format the selected item. ([stackoverflow.com](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/5968553/combobox-selectionboxitemstringformat-not-set-correctly?utm_source=openai))

The introduction of `SelectionBoxItemStringFormat` in .NET Framework 4.5 simplified this process, allowing developers to directly format the selected item without additional workarounds.

sample_1.justification: The solution utilizes Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF) styling and templates. Specifically, it uses the 'SelectionBoxItemStringFormat' property on the ContentPresenter, which was introduced in .NET Framework 3.5 Service Pack 1 in 2008.

ContentStringFormat property.search_query: When was the ContentStringFormat property introduced in WPF?
ContentStringFormat property.evidence:
The `ContentStringFormat` property is a member of the `ContentControl` class in WPF, which is part of the .NET Framework. This property allows you to specify a composite string that formats the `Content` property when it is displayed as a string. It was introduced in WPF 3.5, which was released in November 2007.

The `ContentStringFormat` property is particularly useful when you want to apply a specific format to the content of a `ContentControl` (such as a `Label` or `Button`) without altering the underlying data. For example, you can use it to format numeric values as currency or dates in a specific format.

It's important to note that the `ContentStringFormat` property is only effective when the `Content` property is of a type that can be formatted as a string. If the `Content` is a complex object, you may need to implement a custom `IValueConverter` to achieve the desired formatting.

For more detailed information, you can refer to the official Microsoft documentation on the `ContentStringFormat` property.

Volumetric and Multi-view CNNs for Objec.search_query: Volumetric and Multi-view CNNs for Object Classification on 3D Data Qi et al 2016
Volumetric and Multi-view CNNs for Objec.evidence:
The paper "Volumetric and Multi-View CNNs for Object Classification on 3D Data" by Qi et al. (2016) addresses the challenge of 3D object classification using Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). The authors analyze two prevalent CNN architectures: volumetric CNNs, which operate on 3D voxel grids, and multi-view CNNs, which process multiple 2D renderings of 3D objects. They identify a significant performance gap between these approaches, with multi-view CNNs generally outperforming volumetric ones. This disparity is attributed to factors such as lower resolution in volumetric representations and architectural differences in the networks. ([cv-foundation.org](https://www.cv-foundation.org/openaccess/content_cvpr_2016/papers/Qi_Volumetric_and_Multi-View_CVPR_2016_paper.pdf?utm_source=openai))

To bridge this gap, the authors propose enhancements for both architectures:

1. **Volumetric CNNs**: They introduce two novel network architectures:
   - **Auxiliary Learning Tasks**: By incorporating auxiliary tasks that predict object classes from partial subvolumes, the network is encouraged to focus on local discriminative features, thereby mitigating overfitting.
   - **Anisotropic Probing Kernels**: These kernels project 3D volumes onto 2D representations, enabling the network to learn optimal projections and effectively emulate multi-view CNNs. ([cv-foundation.org](https://www.cv-foundation.org/openaccess/content_cvpr_2016/papers/Qi_Volumetric_and_Multi-View_CVPR_2016_paper.pdf?utm_source=openai))

2. **Multi-View CNNs**: The authors enhance this approach by introducing multi-resolution filtering in 3D, allowing the network to capture features at various scales and improving classification performance. ([cv-foundation.org](https://www.cv-foundation.org/openaccess/content_cvpr_2016/papers/Qi_Volumetric_and_Multi-View_CVPR_2016_paper.pdf?utm_source=openai))

Through extensive experiments, the authors demonstrate that their proposed methods significantly improve the performance of both volumetric and multi-view CNNs, achieving state-of-the-art results in 3D object classification. They also provide a comprehensive analysis of design choices, offering valuable insights into effective strategies for 3D object recognition. ([cv-foundation.org](https://www.cv-foundation.org/openaccess/content_cvpr_2016/papers/Qi_Volumetric_and_Multi-View_CVPR_2016_paper.pdf?utm_source=openai))

For further details, you can access the full paper here: ([cv-foundation.org](https://www.cv-foundation.org/openaccess/content_cvpr_2016/papers/Qi_Volumetric_and_Multi-View_CVPR_2016_paper.pdf?utm_source=openai))

COVID-19.search_query: When was COVID-19 first identified and named?
COVID-19.evidence: COVID-19, caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, was first identified in December 2019 in Wuhan, China. The World Health Organization (WHO) officially named the disease "COVID-19" on February 11, 2020. The name stands for "Coronavirus Disease 2019," reflecting the year it was first identified. The virus itself was named "SARS-CoV-2" on the same date, indicating its genetic similarity to the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) identified in 2003.

Scientific investigation into COVID-19 o.search_query: When did the WHO and scientific community start investigating the origins of COVID-19?
Scientific investigation into COVID-19 o.evidence:
The World Health Organization (WHO) and the global scientific community began investigating the origins of COVID-19 shortly after the initial outbreak in December 2019. On December 31, 2019, Chinese authorities reported a cluster of pneumonia cases in Wuhan, China, linked to a seafood market. By early January 2020, the WHO was actively monitoring the situation and coordinating with Chinese officials.

In May 2020, the World Health Assembly, comprising 122 WHO member states, called for a comprehensive, independent, and impartial study into the origins of the COVID-19 pandemic. This led to the formation of the WHO-convened Global Study of Origins of SARS-CoV-2, which began in early 2021. A team of international experts visited Wuhan in January 2021 to investigate the virus's origins, focusing on potential zoonotic transmission and other hypotheses. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WHO-convened_Global_Study_of_Origins_of_SARS-CoV-2?utm_source=openai))

The investigation faced challenges, including limited access to critical data from China, such as genetic sequences and lab safety records. In June 2025, the WHO's Scientific Advisory Group for the Origins of Novel Pathogens (SAGO) released a report stating that, due to insufficient data, neither the zoonotic transmission nor the laboratory leak hypothesis could be definitively confirmed or excluded. The report emphasized the need for greater transparency and cooperation to prevent future pandemics. ([apnews.com](https://apnews.com/article/5e0f66341e440181d7335e3857a3da7a?utm_source=openai))

In the United States, the House Foreign Affairs Committee began its investigation into the origins of SARS-CoV-2 on March 16, 2020, publishing a final report in late September 2020. The committee continued to examine new information as it became available, including through expert testimony. ([foreignaffairs.house.gov](https://foreignaffairs.house.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/ORIGINS-OF-COVID-19-REPORT.pdf?utm_source=openai))

Overall, the investigation into the origins of COVID-19 has been a complex and ongoing process, involving multiple international and national entities, and continues to evolve as new information emerges.

COVID-19 pandemic.search_query: When was the name COVID-19 officially adopted by the WHO?
COVID-19 pandemic.evidence:
The World Health Organization (WHO) officially named the disease COVID-19 on February 11, 2020. The name stands for "coronavirus disease 2019," reflecting the year it was first identified. This designation was chosen to avoid stigmatization and to provide a standard format for naming future coronavirus outbreaks. ([who.int](https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/technical-guidance/naming-the-coronavirus-disease-%28covid-2019%29-and-the-virus-that-causes-it?utm_source=openai))

Prior to this, the disease was referred to as "2019-nCoV" or "novel coronavirus," and sometimes colloquially as "Wuhan virus." The WHO's guidelines for naming infectious diseases, established in 2015, discourage names that reference specific locations, animals, individuals, or groups of people to prevent negative impacts such as stigmatization. ([who.int](https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/technical-guidance/naming-the-coronavirus-disease-%28covid-2019%29-and-the-virus-that-causes-it?utm_source=openai))

On the same day, the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) named the virus responsible for COVID-19 as SARS-CoV-2, due to its genetic similarity to the virus that caused the 2003 SARS outbreak. ([who.int](https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/technical-guidance/naming-the-coronavirus-disease-%28covid-2019%29-and-the-virus-that-causes-it?utm_source=openai))


## WHO's Naming of COVID-19 and Its Significance:
- [What's in a Name? Why WHO's Formal Name for the New Coronavirus Disease Matters](https://time.com/5782284/who-name-coronavirus-covid-19/?utm_source=openai), Published on Tuesday, February 11

Investigation into COVID-19 origins.search_query: When did the scientific investigation into the origins of COVID-19 begin?
Investigation into COVID-19 origins.evidence:
Scientific investigations into the origins of COVID-19 began shortly after the virus was identified in late 2019. On December 31, 2019, China reported the outbreak to the World Health Organization (WHO), prompting immediate global attention. In early 2020, the U.S. intelligence community initiated inquiries into the virus's origins, including the possibility of a laboratory leak. By April 2020, the Office of the Director of National Intelligence stated that the virus was not man-made or genetically modified. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Origin_of_SARS-CoV-2?utm_source=openai))

In May 2020, the World Health Assembly called for a comprehensive, independent study into the origins of COVID-19. The WHO began negotiations with China to conduct this study, which was later referred to as the WHO-convened Global Study of Origins of SARS-CoV-2. The study's first phase, conducted in early 2021, concluded that a zoonotic origin was "extremely unlikely," favoring a natural spillover from bats to humans, possibly through an intermediary animal. The lab-leak hypothesis was considered "extremely unlikely" due to safety protocols at the Wuhan Institute of Virology. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WHO-convened_Global_Study_of_Origins_of_SARS-CoV-2?utm_source=openai))

Despite these efforts, the exact origins of COVID-19 remain unresolved. In June 2025, a WHO expert group released a final report affirming that zoonotic transmission was the most plausible hypothesis but acknowledged that limited access to critical data from China prevented a definitive conclusion. ([apnews.com](https://apnews.com/article/5e0f66341e440181d7335e3857a3da7a?utm_source=openai))

In the United States, the COVID-19 Origin Act of 2023 mandated the declassification of information related to the virus's origins. The declassified report, released in June 2023, found that the U.S. Intelligence Community was divided between the natural spillover and lab-associated incident hypotheses, with most agencies assessing that SARS-CoV-2 was not developed as a biological weapon. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_Origin_Act_of_2023?utm_source=openai))

These ongoing investigations underscore the global scientific community's commitment to understanding the origins of COVID-19 to prevent future pandemics.

COVID-19.evidence:
The World Health Organization (WHO) officially named the disease caused by the novel coronavirus as "COVID-19" on February 11, 2020. The name stands for "coronavirus disease 2019," with "CO" representing "corona," "VI" for "virus," "D" for "disease," and "19" denoting the year 2019 when the first cases were reported. ([who.int](https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/technical-guidance/naming-the-coronavirus-disease-%28covid-2019%29-and-the-virus-that-causes-it?utm_source=openai))

Prior to this, the disease was referred to as "2019-nCoV" (2019 novel coronavirus) or "Wuhan virus." The WHO's naming guidelines aim to avoid using geographic locations, animals, or individuals' names to prevent stigmatization. ([who.int](https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/technical-guidance/naming-the-coronavirus-disease-%28covid-2019%29-and-the-virus-that-causes-it?utm_source=openai))

On the same day, the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) named the virus responsible for COVID-19 as "SARS-CoV-2," indicating its genetic similarity to the virus that caused the 2003 SARS outbreak. ([who.int](https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/technical-guidance/naming-the-coronavirus-disease-%28covid-2019%29-and-the-virus-that-causes-it?utm_source=openai))

COVID-19 origin investigation.search_query: When did scientific investigations into the origins of COVID-19 begin?
COVID-19 origin investigation.evidence:
Scientific investigations into the origins of COVID-19 began in earnest in early 2020, shortly after the virus was identified. On January 31, 2020, a team of scientists led by the World Health Organization (WHO) visited the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market in Wuhan, China, to investigate the origins of COVID-19. The WHO investigation determined that despite cluster cases there in an early outbreak and some contaminated surfaces found, no infected animal was found, concluding that human-to-human transmission at the market was likely, with the origin site still unknown. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huanan_Seafood_Wholesale_Market?utm_source=openai))

In March 2020, a group of prominent virologists published a letter in *Nature Medicine* titled "The Proximal Origin of SARS-CoV-2," analyzing the virus's genome and concluding that it was not a laboratory construct or purposefully manipulated virus. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_proximal_origin_of_SARS-CoV-2?utm_source=openai))

In May 2020, the World Health Assembly passed a motion calling for a "comprehensive, independent and impartial" study into the COVID-19 pandemic. This led to the formation of the WHO-convened Global Study of Origins of SARS-CoV-2, which began in early 2021. The study concluded that the most likely origin of COVID-19 was a zoonotic event from a virus circulating in bats, likely through another animal carrier, and that the time of transmission to humans was likely towards the end of 2019. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WHO-convened_Global_Study_of_Origins_of_SARS-CoV-2?utm_source=openai))

In the United States, the government initiated its own investigations into the virus's origins. On February 6, 2020, the director of the White House's Office of Science and Technology Policy requested the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine to convene a meeting of experts to assess the data needed to understand the evolutionary origins of COVID-19. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Origin_of_SARS-CoV-2?utm_source=openai))

These early efforts laid the foundation for ongoing research into the origins of COVID-19, which continues to be a subject of scientific inquiry and international collaboration.

Scientific investigation into COVID-19 o.evidence:
Investigations into the origins of COVID-19 began shortly after the virus was identified in December 2019. On December 31, 2019, Chinese authorities initiated an inquiry into the outbreak in Wuhan, focusing on the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market, which was linked to many early cases. ([health.wusf.usf.edu](https://health.wusf.usf.edu/health-news-florida/2024-04-22/toxic-how-the-search-for-the-origins-of-covid-19-turned-politically-poisonous?utm_source=openai))

In early 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) prioritized understanding the virus's origins. In May 2020, the World Health Assembly passed a motion calling for a "comprehensive, independent and impartial" study into the COVID-19 pandemic. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Origin_of_SARS-CoV-2?utm_source=openai))

The United States also initiated investigations into the virus's origins. On February 6, 2020, the director of the White House's Office of Science and Technology Policy requested the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine to convene a meeting of experts to assess data needed to understand the evolutionary origins of COVID-19. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Origin_of_SARS-CoV-2?utm_source=openai))

These early efforts laid the groundwork for subsequent investigations by various international and governmental bodies into the origins of COVID-19.

While the pandemic began in late 2019, the formal international investigation by the WHO and the publication of its initial findings occurred in early 2021, making that the most appropriate year for a model to speak confidently about 'ongoing investigation' into the virus's origins.

COVID-19 Naming.search_query: When did the WHO name COVID-19?
COVID-19 Naming.evidence:
The World Health Organization (WHO) officially named the disease caused by the novel coronavirus "COVID-19" on February 11, 2020. The name stands for "coronavirus disease 2019," reflecting the year it was first identified. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus explained that "CO" stands for "corona," "VI" for "virus," "D" for "disease," and "19" for the year 2019. ([who.int](https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/technical-guidance/naming-the-coronavirus-disease-%28covid-2019%29-and-the-virus-that-causes-it?utm_source=openai))

This naming convention was chosen to avoid stigmatizing any specific location, animal, individual, or group, aligning with WHO's guidelines to prevent the use of names that could be inaccurate or discriminatory. ([who.int](https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/technical-guidance/naming-the-coronavirus-disease-%28covid-2019%29-and-the-virus-that-causes-it?utm_source=openai))

On the same day, the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) named the virus responsible for COVID-19 "SARS-CoV-2," indicating its genetic similarity to the virus responsible for the 2003 SARS outbreak. ([who.int](https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/technical-guidance/naming-the-coronavirus-disease-%28covid-2019%29-and-the-virus-that-causes-it?utm_source=openai))

WHO-China joint study on COVID-19 origin.search_query: When was the WHO report on the origins of COVID-19 released?
WHO-China joint study on COVID-19 origin.evidence:
The World Health Organization (WHO) released its final report on the origins of COVID-19 on June 27, 2025. This report, produced by the Scientific Advisory Group for the Origins of Novel Pathogens (SAGO), concluded that the most plausible explanation for the emergence of SARS-CoV-2 is zoonotic spillover—meaning the virus likely jumped from animals to humans, either directly from bats or through an intermediate host. However, the report also acknowledged that insufficient data prevented a definitive conclusion, leaving all hypotheses, including a potential laboratory origin, still under consideration. ([who.int](https://www.who.int/news/item/27-06-2025-who-scientific-advisory-group-issues-report-on-origins-of-covid-19?utm_source=openai))

The SAGO group emphasized the need for greater transparency and data sharing, particularly from China, to fully understand the origins of the virus and to prevent future pandemics. Despite these calls, the investigation faced challenges due to limited access to critical information, such as genetic sequences from early COVID-19 cases and detailed records from laboratories in Wuhan. ([who.int](https://www.who.int/news/item/27-06-2025-who-scientific-advisory-group-issues-report-on-origins-of-covid-19?utm_source=openai))

This final report followed an earlier assessment by the WHO-convened team in March 2021, which also leaned towards a natural origin of the virus but faced similar limitations in data access. ([nationalgeographic.com](https://www.nationalgeographic.com/science/article/heres-what-the-who-report-found-on-the-origins-of-covid-19?utm_source=openai))

Munich Agreement.search_query: When was the Munich Agreement signed?
Munich Agreement.evidence:
The Munich Agreement was signed on September 30, 1938, in Munich, Germany. This accord permitted Nazi Germany's annexation of the Sudetenland, a region of Czechoslovakia predominantly inhabited by ethnic Germans. The agreement was signed by Adolf Hitler of Germany, Neville Chamberlain of the United Kingdom, Édouard Daladier of France, and Benito Mussolini of Italy. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Munich_Agreement?utm_source=openai))

The Munich Agreement is often cited as a classic example of the policy of appeasement, where Western democracies conceded to some of Hitler's demands in an attempt to prevent a larger conflict. Despite these efforts, the agreement failed to prevent World War II, which began less than a year later. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/event/Munich-Agreement?utm_source=openai))

Multi-level sorting.evidence:
Multi-key sorting algorithms are designed to sort data based on multiple attributes or keys, which is particularly useful when dealing with complex data structures like records or tuples. The development of these algorithms has evolved over time, with several key milestones:

**Early Developments:**

- **Merge Sort (1945):** John von Neumann introduced merge sort, a divide-and-conquer algorithm that efficiently sorts data by recursively dividing the list and merging sorted sublists. While not inherently a multi-key sort, merge sort laid the foundation for stable sorting algorithms, which maintain the relative order of equal elements—a crucial property for multi-key sorting. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merge_sort?utm_source=openai))

**Advancements in Multi-Key Sorting:**

- **Multi-Key Quicksort (Mid-1990s):** Jon Bentley and Robert Sedgewick developed the multi-key quicksort, also known as three-way radix quicksort. This algorithm combines quicksort and radix sort principles to efficiently sort strings with shared prefixes. It partitions the data into three groups based on the current key, recursively sorting each group. This approach significantly improves sorting performance for multi-key data. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-key_quicksort?utm_source=openai))

- **Spreadsort (2002):** Steven J. Ross introduced Spreadsort, a hybrid sorting algorithm that merges distribution-based sorting (like radix sort) with comparison-based sorting (like quicksort and mergesort). Spreadsort is particularly effective for sorting large datasets with structured distributions, offering high efficiency and scalability. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spreadsort?utm_source=openai))

**Recent Innovations:**

- **Multiple Pivot Sorting Algorithms (2005):** A patent application described a multiple pivot sorting algorithm that extends the quicksort method by using multiple pivots to partition the data into smaller sublists. This approach aims to enhance sorting efficiency, especially for large datasets. ([patents.justia.com](https://patents.justia.com/patent/20070088699?utm_source=openai))

- **GPU-Optimized Multi-Key Sorting (2017):** Researchers developed GPU-efficient multi-way mergesort algorithms tailored for modern GPU architectures. These algorithms leverage parallel processing capabilities to achieve high performance in sorting large datasets, demonstrating the adaptability of multi-key sorting techniques to emerging hardware platforms. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/1702.07961?utm_source=openai))

The history of multi-key sorting algorithms reflects a continuous effort to improve sorting efficiency and adaptability across various data types and computing environments.

JSON (JavaScript Object Notation).search_query: When was JSON first popularized by Douglas Crockford?
JSON (JavaScript Object Notation).evidence: Douglas Crockford first popularized JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) in the early 2000s while working at State Software. In April 2001, he and Chip Morningstar sent the first JSON message, marking the inception of this lightweight data interchange format. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JSON?utm_source=openai)) Recognizing the need for a standardized format, Crockford registered the domain json.org in 2002 to provide documentation and specifications for JSON. Multi-level sorting logic.evidence:
Multi-level sorting algorithms, also known as multi-key sorting algorithms, are designed to sort data based on multiple criteria or keys. These algorithms are particularly useful when dealing with complex data structures or when a single sorting criterion is insufficient. The development of multi-level sorting algorithms has evolved over time, with several key milestones:

**Early Developments:**

- **Merge Sort (1945):** Introduced by John von Neumann, merge sort is a fundamental comparison-based sorting algorithm that employs a divide-and-conquer approach. It recursively divides the list into sublists and merges them to produce a sorted list. Merge sort is stable, meaning it preserves the relative order of equal elements. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merge_sort?utm_source=openai))

- **Quicksort (1961):** Developed by Tony Hoare, quicksort is another comparison-based sorting algorithm that selects a pivot element and partitions the list into elements less than and greater than the pivot. It then recursively sorts the sublists. Quicksort is known for its efficiency and is widely used in practice.

**Advancements in Multi-Level Sorting:**

- **Multi-Key Quicksort (1990s):** Recognizing the need to sort data based on multiple keys, researchers developed multi-key quicksort algorithms. These algorithms extend the traditional quicksort by incorporating multiple pivot elements, allowing for sorting based on multiple criteria simultaneously. This approach is particularly useful for sorting complex data structures where multiple attributes need to be considered. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/1510.04676?utm_source=openai))

- **Spreadsort (2002):** Invented by Steven J. Ross, spreadsort is a sorting algorithm that combines concepts from distribution-based sorts, such as radix sort and bucket sort, with partitioning concepts from comparison sorts like quicksort and mergesort. It is particularly efficient for sorting large datasets with a uniform distribution. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spreadsort?utm_source=openai))

- **Samplesort (1970s):** Introduced by W.D. Frazer and A.C. McKellar, samplesort is a divide-and-conquer algorithm often used in parallel processing systems. It partitions the array into sub-intervals or buckets and then sorts each bucket individually before concatenating them together. Samplesort is particularly effective when the array is non-uniformly distributed. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samplesort?utm_source=openai))

- **Cubesort (2014):** Cubesort is a parallel sorting algorithm that builds a self-balancing multi-dimensional array from the keys to be sorted. After each key is inserted, the cube can be rapidly converted to an array. This approach is particularly effective for parallel processing systems. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubesort?utm_source=openai))

**Recent Developments:**

- **Multiway Mergesort for GPU Architectures (2017):** With the advent of parallel computing, researchers have developed multiway mergesort algorithms optimized for GPU architectures. These algorithms employ partitioning techniques that expose parallelism, making them efficient for modern GPU hardware. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/1702.07961?utm_source=openai))

- **Robust Massively Parallel Sorting (2016):** This research focuses on distributed memory parallel sorting algorithms that scale to large machines and are robust with respect to input size and distribution. The study presents algorithms that cover a range of input sizes and distributions, demonstrating significant performance improvements over conventional methods. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/1606.08766?utm_source=openai))

The history of multi-level sorting algorithms reflects a continuous effort to develop efficient methods for sorting complex and large datasets based on multiple criteria. Advancements in parallel computing and hardware architectures continue to drive innovation in this field.

Bash 3.1 (array append syntax).search_query: When was Bash 3.1 released with array append operator?
Bash 3.1 (array append syntax).evidence:
Bash 3.1, released on December 9, 2005, introduced the `+=` operator for appending elements to arrays. ([lists.gnu.org](https://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/info-gnu/2005-12/msg00003.html?utm_source=openai)) This feature allows you to add elements to an array without specifying an index, similar to the behavior in languages like PHP.

For example, to append elements to an array in Bash 3.1 and later:

```bash
my_array=()
my_array+=('element1')
my_array+=('element2')
```

This syntax appends `'element1'` and `'element2'` to `my_array`. ([stackoverflow.com](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1951506/add-a-new-element-to-an-array-without-specifying-the-index-in-bash?utm_source=openai))

Prior to Bash 3.1, appending to arrays required alternative methods, such as assigning to the next available index:

```bash
my_array[${#my_array[@]}]='element1'
```

This approach manually calculates the next index by determining the current length of the array. ([unix.stackexchange.com](https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/64427/bash-3-0-not-supporting-lists?utm_source=openai))

The introduction of the `+=` operator in Bash 3.1 streamlined array manipulation, making scripts more concise and easier to read.

fio 2.0 (binary prefix support).evidence:
Fio 2.0, a flexible I/O tester, was released on March 17, 2013. ([opencsw.org](https://www.opencsw.org/qa/package/fio/?utm_source=openai)) In this release, the software introduced support for binary prefixes, aligning with the International System of Units (SI) and the International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC) standards. This means that data sizes can be specified using binary prefixes such as KiB (kibibyte), MiB (mebibyte), GiB (gibibyte), and so on, where:

- 1 KiB = 1,024 bytes
- 1 MiB = 1,048,576 bytes
- 1 GiB = 1,073,741,824 bytes

This enhancement allows for more precise and standardized representation of data sizes, reducing ambiguity between binary and decimal interpretations. fio version 2.0.search_query: fio 2.0 release date and output format changes
fio version 2.0.evidence:
The Flexible I/O Tester (fio) is a widely used benchmarking tool for storage systems. The 2.0 series of fio introduced several enhancements, including changes to the output format.

**Release Date:**
The fio 2.0 series began with version 2.0.3, released on February 20, 2012. ([bsdio.com](https://bsdio.com/fio/releases/archive/?utm_source=openai))

**Output Format Changes:**
In fio 2.0, the terse output format was introduced to provide a concise summary of benchmark results. To enable this format, use the `--minimal` or `--output-format=terse` command-line options. The terse output includes the following fields:

- **terse version**
- **fio version**
- **jobname**
- **groupid**
- **error**

For read operations, the output includes:

- **Total IO (KiB)**
- **Bandwidth (KiB/sec)**
- **IOPS**
- **Runtime (msec)**
- **Submission latency: min, max, mean, stdev (usec)**
- **Completion latency: min, max, mean, stdev (usec)**
- **Completion latency percentiles: 20 fields**
- **Total latency: min, max, mean, stdev (usec)**
- **Bandwidth (KiB/s): min, max, aggregate percentage of total, mean, stdev**

For write operations, the output includes:

- **Total IO (KiB)**
- **Bandwidth (KiB/sec)**
- **IOPS**
- **Runtime (msec)**
- **Submission latency: min, max, mean, stdev (usec)**
- **Completion latency: min, max, mean, stdev (usec)**
- **Completion latency percentiles: 20 fields**
- **Total latency: min, max, mean, stdev (usec)**
- **Bandwidth (KiB/s): min, max, aggregate percentage of total, mean, stdev**
- **CPU usage: user, system, context switches, major faults, minor faults**
- **IO depths: <=1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, >=64**
- **IO latencies microseconds: <=2, 4, 10, 20, 50, 100, 250, 500, 750, 1000**

These changes were implemented to provide a more streamlined and efficient way to interpret benchmark results. ([android.googlesource.com](https://android.googlesource.com/platform/external/fio/%2B/a64f0e1024b1cc29595e5c0b0848a775fed886fd/HOWTO?utm_source=openai))

For a comprehensive list of all changes and updates in the fio 2.0 series, you can refer to the official release notes on GitHub. ([github.com](https://github.com/axboe/fio/releases?utm_source=openai))

The JavaConfig project, which provided Java-based configuration for Spring, was first conceived in 2005. It became a fully supported effort and moved toward a 1.0 release, with the first milestone release (1.0 M3) published in 2007. ([docs.spring.io](https://docs.spring.io/spring-javaconfig/docs/1.0.0.m3/reference/html/overview.html?utm_source=openai))

Therefore, Java-based configuration was introduced in Spring 3.0 in 2009, building upon earlier annotation-based configuration introduced in Spring 2.5 in 2007.

Arthur Ashkin optical levitation paper.evidence:
Arthur Ashkin first demonstrated the optical levitation of small transparent glass spheres in 1971. In a seminal experiment, he and his colleague Joseph Dziedzic used a single vertically directed focused continuous-wave laser beam to stably levitate a 20-micrometer-diameter glass sphere in both air and vacuum environments. This groundbreaking work, titled "Optical Levitation by Radiation Pressure," was published in *Applied Physics Letters* in October 1971. ([colab.ws](https://colab.ws/articles/10.1063%2F1.1653919?utm_source=openai))

This achievement laid the foundation for the development of optical tweezers, a technique that has since become instrumental in manipulating microscopic particles, including biological molecules and cells. ([nobelprize.org](https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/physics/2018/popular-information/?utm_source=openai))

Ornstein-Uhlenbeck theory of Brownian mo.search_query: When did Ornstein and Uhlenbeck publish their work on Brownian motion?
Ornstein-Uhlenbeck theory of Brownian mo.evidence:
Leonard S. Ornstein and George E. Uhlenbeck published their seminal work on Brownian motion, titled "On the Theory of Brownian Motion," in 1930. This paper appeared in the journal *Physical Review*, volume 36, issue 5, spanning pages 823 to 841. ([colab.ws](https://colab.ws/articles/10.1103%2Fphysrev.36.823?utm_source=openai))

In this groundbreaking study, Ornstein and Uhlenbeck introduced the stochastic process now known as the Ornstein–Uhlenbeck process. This process models the velocity of a particle undergoing Brownian motion, incorporating both random collisions and a frictional force that causes the particle to revert to a mean position over time. Their work provided a more comprehensive understanding of Brownian motion by accounting for the inertia of particles, thereby extending Einstein's earlier theoretical framework. ([galileo-unbound.blog](https://galileo-unbound.blog/2024/04/24/the-ubiquitous-george-uhlenbeck/?utm_source=openai))

Huang et al. / Franosch et al. liquid Br.search_query: When was the instantaneous velocity of Brownian motion first measured in a liquid?
Huang et al. / Franosch et al. liquid Br.evidence:
The first direct measurement of the instantaneous velocity of Brownian particles in a liquid was achieved in 2010 by researchers at the University of Texas at Austin. They utilized optical tweezers to trap micrometer-sized beads suspended in water and acetone, allowing them to observe the particles' rapid, random motion. This groundbreaking experiment provided direct verification of Einstein's energy equipartition theorem for Brownian particles. ([sciencedaily.com](https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2010/05/100520141206.htm?utm_source=openai))

Prior to this, in 1900, Felix M. Exner conducted the first quantitative study of Brownian motion by measuring the velocity of Brownian particles suspended in water. However, his results were about three orders of magnitude smaller than those predicted by the energy equipartition theorem. ([raizenlab.ph.utexas.edu](https://raizenlab.ph.utexas.edu/pub/jianyong19.pdf?utm_source=openai))

Albert Einstein had predicted in 1907 that observing the instantaneous velocity of Brownian particles would be impossible due to the extremely short timescales involved. The 2010 experiment successfully challenged this assertion, demonstrating that such measurements are indeed feasible. ([news.utexas.edu](https://news.utexas.edu/2010/05/20/physicists-prove-einstein-wrong-with-observation-of-instantaneous-velocity-in-brownian-particles/?utm_source=openai))

Unprefixed CSS transform property suppor.search_query: When was unprefixed CSS transform support added to browsers?
Unprefixed CSS transform property suppor.evidence:
Unprefixed support for the CSS `transform` property was introduced across major browsers in the early to mid-2010s. Here's a timeline highlighting when various browsers added support:

- **Internet Explorer**: Introduced support for unprefixed `transform` in version 10, released in 2012. ([stackoverflow.com](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/28545533/how-should-you-prefix-transform-properties-in-css3-animations?utm_source=openai))

- **Firefox**: Removed the `-moz-` prefix starting with version 16, released in 2012. ([stackoverflow.com](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/28545533/how-should-you-prefix-transform-properties-in-css3-animations?utm_source=openai))

- **Chrome**: Began supporting unprefixed `transform` in version 36, released in 2014. ([stackoverflow.com](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/28545533/how-should-you-prefix-transform-properties-in-css3-animations?utm_source=openai))

- **Safari**: Transitioned to unprefixed `transform` with the release of Safari 9 in 2015. ([css-tricks.com](https://css-tricks.com/is-vendor-prefixing-dead/?utm_source=openai))

- **Opera**: Opera Developer 23.0, released in 2014, added support for unprefixed `transform`. ([betanews.com](https://betanews.com/2014/05/14/opera-developer-adds-support-for-unprefixed-css-transforms-fails-to-ignite-user-imagination/?utm_source=openai))

By 2015, most major browsers had adopted unprefixed support for the `transform` property, aligning with the standard CSS3 specifications.

The CSS `transform` property, which allows for transformations such as scaling, rotating, skewing, and translating elements, was first introduced in WebKit on October 26, 2007. ([webkit.org](https://webkit.org/blog/130/css-transforms/?utm_source=openai)) This initial implementation required the `-webkit-` prefix.

The unprefixed `transform` property was supported in WebKit starting from July 2008, coinciding with the release of iPhone OS 2.0. ([webkit.org](https://webkit.org/blog/11420/css-individual-transform-properties/?utm_source=openai))

The `skew()` function, which skews an element along the X and Y axes, was introduced in Firefox 3.5, released in June 2009. ([udn.realityripple.com](https://udn.realityripple.com/docs/Web/CSS/transform-function?utm_source=openai)) It was also supported in Safari 3.1, released in March 2008. ([udn.realityripple.com](https://udn.realityripple.com/docs/Web/CSS/transform-function?utm_source=openai))

Therefore, both the `transform` property and the `skew()` function were supported unprefixed in major browsers by mid-2009.

HTML5 Doctype.search_query: When was the HTML5 doctype first introduced?
HTML5 Doctype.evidence: The HTML5 doctype, `<!DOCTYPE html>`, was introduced in the first public working draft of the HTML5 specification released by the Web Hypertext Application Technology Working Group (WHATWG) on January 22, 2008. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTML5?utm_source=openai)) This simplified doctype was designed to trigger standards-compliant rendering modes in web browsers, marking a departure from the more complex doctypes used in previous HTML versions.

Commercial use of bamboo in caskets.search_query: When did bamboo caskets become commercially available in the funeral industry?
Commercial use of bamboo in caskets.evidence:
Bamboo caskets have been available in the funeral industry for several decades, with their commercial introduction varying by region. In the United Kingdom, Ecoffins, founded by William Wainman, began producing bamboo coffins in the early 2000s. Wainman, inspired by his experiences in China, established a factory in Hunan province to craft these eco-friendly coffins. The British Embassy in Beijing requested a small run of bamboo coffins, which sold quickly as natural burials gained popularity in the UK. ([ecoffins.co.uk](https://www.ecoffins.co.uk/pages/history?utm_source=openai))

In the United States, the adoption of bamboo caskets has been more recent. In 2018, Passages International, Inc. introduced environmentally friendly cremation containers made from sustainably sourced bamboo. These products offered funeral homes a dignified and green alternative to traditional cardboard boxes used for cremation. ([etern.life](https://etern.life/passages-international-launches-fair-trade-alternatives-to-entry-level-cardboard-containers/?utm_source=openai))

The global market for bamboo caskets has been expanding, driven by increasing environmental awareness and the demand for sustainable burial options. As of 2023, the green funeral products market was valued at over $2 billion, with bamboo-based solutions leading innovation in sustainable end-of-life care. ([phoenixnestcoffins.com](https://phoenixnestcoffins.com/sustainability-and-the-rise-of-green-burials-the-global-ascendancy-of-woven-coffins-and-chinas-linshu-linyi-pioneers/?utm_source=openai))

In summary, bamboo caskets became commercially available in the funeral industry in the early 2000s, with their adoption gaining momentum in the following decades as sustainability became a more prominent consideration in funeral practices.

Mass production of steel and aluminum ca.search_query: When did metal caskets become common in the United States?
Mass production of steel and aluminum ca.evidence:
Metal caskets were first introduced in the United States in the late 1840s. In 1848, Dr. Almond D. Fisk patented the Fisk Metallic Burial Case, a cast-iron coffin designed to be airtight and indestructible. This innovation was particularly appealing to wealthier families and those concerned about grave robbers. However, due to their high cost—ranging from $40 to $170 at the time—and substantial weight, these metal caskets did not gain widespread popularity during the Civil War era. ([civilwarmed.org](https://www.civilwarmed.org/coffins-to-caskets/?utm_source=openai))

The mass production of metal caskets began in the early 20th century. Batesville Casket Company, established in 1884, started manufacturing metal caskets in 1918. By the 1950s, metal caskets had become more prevalent, accounting for a significant portion of the casket market in the United States. ([assemblymag.com](https://www.assemblymag.com/articles/87043-the-history-of-caskets?utm_source=openai))

Today, metal caskets are the most common type used in the U.S., comprising approximately two-thirds of all caskets sold. They are available in various materials, including solid bronze, solid copper, stainless steel, and carbon steel, offering a range of durability and price points. ([gorgenfh.com](https://www.gorgenfh.com/resources/casket-selection?utm_source=openai))

Ancient Egyptian Sarcophagi.search_query: History of Ancient Egyptian sarcophagi and burial practices
Ancient Egyptian Sarcophagi.evidence:
Ancient Egyptian sarcophagi and burial practices reflect the civilization's profound beliefs in the afterlife and the importance of preserving the body for the journey beyond.

**Sarcophagi in Ancient Egypt**

The term "sarcophagus" originates from the Greek words "sarx" (flesh) and "phagein" (to eat), referring to a stone coffin. In ancient Egypt, the earliest stone coffins appeared during the 3rd Dynasty (c. 2650–2575 BCE), designed to resemble mud-brick palaces with false doors and windows. By the 11th Dynasty (c. 2081–1991 BCE), box-like wooden or limestone sarcophagi became common. The 17th Dynasty (c. 1630–1540 BCE) introduced anthropoid coffins shaped like human figures, often adorned with painted portraits. Royalty sometimes used coffins made of precious metals, such as Tutankhamun's solid gold coffin. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/topic/sarcophagus?utm_source=openai))

**Burial Practices**

Ancient Egyptians believed in an afterlife where the deceased would continue their existence. To ensure a safe journey, they practiced mummification to preserve the body. Artifacts like the "Coffin of Nedjemankh," a gilded wooden coffin from the late Ptolemaic Period, exemplify this practice. Discovered in 2011, it was repatriated to Egypt in 2019 after being looted. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coffin_of_Nedjemankh?utm_source=openai))

The Saqqara necropolis, serving as the burial ground for Memphis, has yielded numerous sarcophagi. In 2020, archaeologists uncovered 59 sealed sarcophagi dating back over 2,500 years, many belonging to priests and prominent figures of the 26th Dynasty. ([aljazeera.com](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/10/3/egypt-unveils-59-ancient-coffins-in-major-archaeological-discover?utm_source=openai))

These discoveries offer valuable insights into the funerary art and religious practices of ancient Egypt, highlighting the civilization's dedication to honoring the deceased and their journey into the afterlife.


## Recent Discoveries in Ancient Egyptian Funerary Practices:
- [Looted ancient sarcophagus returned to Egypt from US](https://apnews.com/article/21fe41acdce6ba04b8183c0cda9afa3f?utm_source=openai), Published on Monday, January 02
- [How to make a mummy: Ancient Egyptian workshop has new clues](https://apnews.com/article/68735c4de698a1662897910e8879e283?utm_source=openai), Published on Wednesday, February 01

Industrial Revolution Cast Iron Caskets.search_query: When were cast iron and lead-lined caskets introduced?
Industrial Revolution Cast Iron Caskets.evidence:
Cast iron caskets were introduced in the United States in 1848 when Almond D. Fisk patented his "metallic burial case." These airtight caskets were designed to preserve the body and deter grave robbers. They gained popularity among wealthier families in the mid-19th century. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisk_metallic_burial_case?utm_source=openai))

The use of lead-lined coffins dates back centuries, with evidence suggesting the practice began as early as the reign of King Edward I, who died in 1307. Lead linings help prevent decomposition by sealing in odors and toxins. ([ucl.ac.uk](https://www.ucl.ac.uk/news/headlines/2022/sep/why-royal-coffins-are-lead-lined?utm_source=openai))

In the 19th century, lead linings became more common in royal and high-status burials to ensure the preservation of the body. For example, Queen Elizabeth II's casket, used in her 2022 funeral, was lined with lead to maintain the body's condition during the extended period it was on display. ([washingtonpost.com](https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2022/09/21/queen-elizabeth-coffin-lead-burial/?utm_source=openai))

In summary, cast iron caskets were introduced in 1848, while the practice of lead-lining coffins has a much longer history, with significant use in royal burials from the 14th century onward.

Modern Steel and Aluminum Caskets.search_query: When did steel and aluminum caskets become common in America?
Modern Steel and Aluminum Caskets.evidence:
Steel and aluminum caskets became more common in the United States during the early to mid-20th century. The first metal caskets appeared in the late 1840s, with Dr. Almond D. Fisk patenting a cast-iron, airtight model in 1848. These early metal caskets were expensive and primarily used by wealthier families. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisk_metallic_burial_case?utm_source=openai))

The widespread adoption of metal caskets began in the 1910s and 1920s. In 1918, Batesville Casket Company introduced mass-produced metal caskets, making them more accessible to the general public. ([assemblymag.com](https://www.assemblymag.com/articles/87043-the-history-of-caskets?utm_source=openai)) During World War II, the demand for metal caskets increased, leading to further advancements in mass production techniques. By the mid-1970s, metal caskets accounted for approximately two-thirds of all caskets sold in the U.S. ([latimes.com](https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-2007-jan-05-fi-casket5-story.html?utm_source=openai))

Aluminum caskets, specifically, gained popularity in the 1960s and 1970s. Aurora Casket Company began producing stainless steel caskets in 1966, and other manufacturers followed suit, offering a variety of metal caskets to meet consumer preferences. ([company-histories.com](https://www.company-histories.com/Aurora-Casket-Company-Inc-Company-History.html?utm_source=openai))

Today, metal caskets, including those made from steel and aluminum, are standard in the U.S. funeral industry, offering durability and a range of design options to meet diverse consumer needs.

Green Burial Movement and Bamboo Caskets.search_query: When did bamboo caskets and green burial become a trend in the funeral industry?
Green Burial Movement and Bamboo Caskets.evidence:
Bamboo caskets and green burials have gained prominence in the funeral industry over the past few decades, driven by increasing environmental awareness and a desire for sustainable end-of-life practices.

**Green Burials:**

The modern green burial movement began in the early 1990s. In 1993, the first "woodland burial ground" was established in Carlisle, England, offering an alternative to conventional burial methods. This initiative inspired the creation of the United Kingdom's Natural Deathcare Centre, which advocates for environmentally friendly end-of-life rituals. ([apexces.com](https://www.apexces.com/PDFs/cwoUT-rtyTF-NQncH-Final_online_Green_Burial_101.pdf?utm_source=openai))

In the United States, the first exclusively green cemetery, Ramsey Creek Preserve, opened in 1998 in South Carolina. This site emphasized natural burials without embalming chemicals or non-biodegradable materials. ([apexces.com](https://www.apexces.com/PDFs/cwoUT-rtyTF-NQncH-Final_online_Green_Burial_101.pdf?utm_source=openai))

**Bamboo Caskets:**

Bamboo caskets have emerged as a sustainable alternative to traditional wooden or metal caskets. Their adoption has been particularly notable in regions with abundant bamboo resources, such as Asia-Pacific. The global bamboo casket market is projected to expand at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 5.2% through 2030, reflecting increasing demand for eco-friendly funeral solutions. ([accio.com](https://www.accio.com/plp/bamboo-casket?utm_source=openai))

In the United States, the Green Burial Council, established in 2005, has played a significant role in promoting green burial practices, including the use of bamboo caskets. Their efforts have contributed to a growing acceptance of sustainable burial options among consumers. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sustainable_cemetery?utm_source=openai))

Overall, the trend toward bamboo caskets and green burials has been gaining momentum since the early 1990s, with significant growth observed in the 2000s and 2010s as environmental concerns have become more prominent.

2023 Travel Guide Requirement.evidence:
The Virgin Islands, comprising the U.S. Virgin Islands (USVI) and the British Virgin Islands (BVI), offer a diverse array of experiences for travelers. Here's a comprehensive guide to help you plan your visit:

**Overview**

The Virgin Islands are renowned for their pristine beaches, rich history, and vibrant culture. Each island has its unique charm:

- **St. Thomas (USVI):** The most developed island, offering numerous resorts, shopping opportunities, and water sports activities. ([lonelyplanet.com](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/us-virgin-islands?utm_source=openai))

- **St. John (USVI):** Known for its natural beauty, with two-thirds of the island designated as Virgin Islands National Park, making it ideal for hiking and snorkeling. ([lonelyplanet.com](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/us-virgin-islands?utm_source=openai))

- **St. Croix (USVI):** The largest island, offering exceptional scuba diving sites and historical attractions. ([lonelyplanet.com](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/us-virgin-islands?utm_source=openai))

- **Tortola (BVI):** The largest of the British Virgin Islands, featuring Mount Sage National Park, which includes the highest peak in the Virgin Islands, Mount Sage. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Sage_National_Park?utm_source=openai))

**Recent Developments**

- **St. John Land Exchange Act of 2023:** In September 2023, the Virgin Islands Legislature enacted the St. John Land Exchange Act, facilitating the construction of a new K-12 school on St. John by exchanging land with the National Park Service. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._John_Land_Exchange_Act_of_2023?utm_source=openai))

- **St. Croix Water Crisis:** In November 2023, elevated levels of lead, copper, and iron were detected in St. Croix's water supply, leading to a federal state of emergency and the provision of safe drinking water to affected communities. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Croix_water_crisis?utm_source=openai))

**Travel Considerations**

- **Weather:** The Virgin Islands enjoy a tropical climate with warm temperatures year-round. Average temperatures range from 77°F (25°C) to 88°F (31°C). The rainy season typically spans from May to November.

- **Transportation:** Inter-island travel is facilitated by ferries and small aircraft. Major airlines offer flights to the USVI, with connections to the BVI.

- **Accommodations:** Options range from luxury resorts and boutique hotels to vacation rentals and guesthouses. It's advisable to book in advance, especially during peak tourist seasons.

**Activities and Attractions**

- **Beaches:** Coki Beach on St. Thomas is renowned for its snorkeling opportunities, offering clear waters and abundant marine life. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coki_Beach?utm_source=openai))

- **National Parks:** Virgin Islands National Park on St. John provides numerous hiking trails, pristine beaches, and historical sites.

- **Cultural Sites:** Explore the historic towns of Christiansted and Frederiksted on St. Croix, or visit the Sage Mountain National Park on Tortola.

**Travel Tips**

- **Health and Safety:** Stay informed about local health advisories, especially concerning water quality. Ensure you have travel insurance that covers medical emergencies.

- **Local Customs:** Embrace the laid-back Caribbean lifestyle. Engage with local communities respectfully and support local businesses.

- **Environmental Responsibility:** Practice sustainable tourism by minimizing waste, respecting wildlife, and preserving natural habitats.

For a visual overview of St. Thomas, you might find this travel guide video helpful:

[2023 St. Thomas, Virgin Islands Travel Guide](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7aw3au0oowQ&utm_source=openai)


Enjoy your trip to the Virgin Islands!

Beef Island Airport was renamed Terrance B. Lettsome International Airport in February 2001 to honor Terrance B. These developments marked the airport's transition from a basic regional facility, operational since the late 1960s, to a more robust international gateway, though subsequent hurricanes like Irma in 2017 would later necessitate further repairs. ([grokipedia.com](https://grokipedia.com/page/Terrance_B._Lettsome_International_Airport?utm_source=openai))

2023 travel information context.evidence:
The U.S. Virgin Islands (USVI) offers a diverse and vibrant travel experience, with recent developments enhancing its appeal. Here's an updated guide to help you plan your visit:

**Recognition and Awards**

In October 2023, the USVI was honored in Condé Nast Traveler’s Reader’s Choice Awards, being recognized as a top Caribbean island destination. This accolade reflects the islands' growing popularity and the quality of experiences they offer. ([visitusvi.com](https://www.visitusvi.com/press-release/us-virgin-islands-recognized-conde-nast-travelers-2023-readers-choice-award/?utm_source=openai))

**Cultural and Legislative Updates**

- **Equality Act (Virgin Islands):** Signed into law on January 19, 2023, this legislation prohibits discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity, promoting inclusivity and equality within the territory. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Equality_Act_%28Virgin_Islands%29?utm_source=openai))

- **Cannabis Legalization:** As of January 18, 2023, recreational cannabis use is legal in the USVI. While medical use was legalized in 2019, it's important to note that cannabis remains illegal under federal law. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cannabis_in_the_United_States_Virgin_Islands?utm_source=openai))

**Environmental and Infrastructure Developments**

- **St. Croix Water Crisis:** Between October 2023 and January 2024, St. Croix faced a significant water contamination issue due to elevated lead levels. The government declared a state of emergency, and federal resources were deployed to address the crisis and ensure public health. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Croix_water_crisis?utm_source=openai))

- **St. John Land Exchange Act of 2023:** Enacted on September 29, 2023, this act authorized the transfer of Whistling Cay to the National Park Service in exchange for land in Estate Catherineberg. The acquired land is intended for the construction of a new K-12 school on St. John, aiming to improve educational facilities for residents. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._John_Land_Exchange_Act_of_2023?utm_source=openai))

**Sports and International Representation**

The USVI participated in the 2023 Pan American Games held in Santiago, Chile, from October 20 to November 5, 2023. The team comprised 12 athletes competing in six sports, marking the territory's 15th appearance at the Pan American Games. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virgin_Islands_at_the_2023_Pan_American_Games?utm_source=openai))

**Travel Considerations**

- **Weather:** The USVI enjoys a tropical climate with warm temperatures year-round. Average temperatures typically range from 77°F to 88°F (25°C to 31°C). It's advisable to check the latest weather forecasts before your trip.

- **Health and Safety:** Stay informed about local health advisories, especially concerning water quality and any ongoing public health initiatives.

- **Local Laws and Regulations:** Familiarize yourself with local laws, including those related to cannabis use, to ensure a respectful and lawful visit.

By staying informed about these developments, you can enjoy a safe and enriching experience in the U.S. Virgin Islands.

Southern Ocean recognition.search_query: When was the Southern Ocean officially recognized by the International Hydrographic Organization?
Southern Ocean recognition.evidence:
The International Hydrographic Organization (IHO) first recognized the Southern Ocean in 1929. However, due to disputes over its geographical limits and questions about its existence, the IHO removed the Southern Ocean from its official publications in 1953. ([iho.int](https://iho.int/fr/the-international-community-gathers-in-monaco-for-the-iho-assembly?utm_source=openai))

In 2023, the IHO Assembly approved a resolution acknowledging the existence of the Southern Ocean, defining its northern boundary at 60 degrees south latitude. This decision aimed to address the longstanding debates and align with the well-established use of the term "Southern Ocean" by geographers and the scientific community. ([iho.int](https://iho.int/fr/the-international-community-gathers-in-monaco-for-the-iho-assembly?utm_source=openai))

It's important to note that while the IHO has recognized the Southern Ocean, it is not a naming authority. The current edition of the IHO's publication, "Limits of Oceans and Seas" (S-23), published in 1953, does not include the term "Southern Ocean." However, the IHO's General Bathymetric Chart of the Oceans (GEBCO) uses the term in the International Bathymetric Chart of the Southern Ocean (IBCSO). ([iho.int](https://iho.int/uploads/user/Inter-Regional%20Coordination/HCA/HCA18/Status_HCA17_DECISIONS%20and%20ACTIONS_21Feb2022.pdf?utm_source=openai))

In summary, the IHO officially recognized the Southern Ocean in 2023, defining its northern boundary at 60 degrees south latitude.

Southern Ocean recognition.search_query: When did the IHO recognize the Southern Ocean?
Southern Ocean recognition.evidence:
The International Hydrographic Organization (IHO) officially recognized the Southern Ocean in May 2023. During its 3rd Assembly, the IHO approved a resolution acknowledging the Southern Ocean as the global sea area surrounding Antarctica, with its northern limit defined by the 60°S parallel. This decision was influenced by the widespread use of the term "Southern Ocean" by the international scientific community and media. ([iho.int](https://iho.int/uploads/user/About%20IHO/Assembly/Assembly3/DOCUMENTS/PRO%20A3/A3_2023_PRO-3.3_EN_IHO_Resolution_Southern_Ocean_v1.pdf?utm_source=openai))

Historically, the Southern Ocean's status has been contentious. The IHO's 2nd edition of "Limits of Oceans and Seas," published in 1937, included the Southern Ocean. However, in the 3rd edition released in 1953, the Southern Ocean was omitted due to a lack of consensus among member states. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southern_Ocean?utm_source=openai))

In 2000, the IHO proposed redefining the Southern Ocean's boundaries, suggesting it encompass waters south of the 60°S parallel. This proposal was circulated as a draft in 2002 but was not formally adopted at that time. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southern_Ocean?utm_source=openai))

The 2023 resolution by the IHO Assembly marked a significant step in officially recognizing the Southern Ocean, aligning with its established usage in the scientific community.

Yoshitaka Amano.search_query: When did Yoshitaka Amano start working on Final Fantasy?
Yoshitaka Amano.evidence:
Yoshitaka Amano began his involvement with the Final Fantasy series in 1987, when he joined Square (now Square Enix) to work on the original Final Fantasy game for the Nintendo Entertainment System. He provided conceptual designs for the game, contributing both traditional and computer-generated artwork. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoshitaka_Amano?utm_source=openai))

Amano's distinctive artistic style significantly influenced the visual identity of the Final Fantasy franchise. After Final Fantasy VI in 1994, he stepped down as the series' main conceptual, image, and graphic designer. However, he continued to create promotional artwork and design title logos for subsequent installments. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoshitaka_Amano?utm_source=openai))

In 2006, Hironobu Sakaguchi, the creator of Final Fantasy, invited Amano to collaborate on projects at his new company, Mistwalker. Amano and composer Nobuo Uematsu worked together on games like Fairy Fencer F at Compile Heart. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoshitaka_Amano?utm_source=openai))

As of 2025, Amano continues to provide promotional and character artwork for the Final Fantasy series and designs their title logos. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoshitaka_Amano?utm_source=openai))

H.R. Giger.search_query: When was H.R. Giger's work on Alien released?
H.R. Giger.evidence:
H.R. Giger's work on the film *Alien* was released in 1979. He was responsible for designing the iconic alien creature, known as the Xenomorph, which became a central element of the film's success. Giger's unique "biomechanical" art style, blending human forms with machinery, significantly contributed to the film's distinctive aesthetic. ([washingtonpost.com](https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/hr-giger-artist-who-designed-the-creature-in-the-1979-film-alien-dies-at-74/2014/05/13/6818becc-dabb-11e3-8009-71de85b9c527_story.html?utm_source=openai))

In 1979, Giger also published a book titled *Giger's Alien*, which provides an illustrated record of his work on the film, including sketches, paintings, and on-set photographs. This book offers fans an in-depth look at the creative process behind the Xenomorph's design. ([titanbooks.com](https://titanbooks.com/72920-gigers-alien/?utm_source=openai))

In 2026, a reprint of *Giger's Alien* is scheduled for release, allowing new audiences to explore Giger's contributions to the film. ([artbookcollector.com](https://www.artbookcollector.com/post/giger-s-alien-getting-a-2026-reprint?utm_source=openai))

Giger's work on *Alien* earned him an Academy Award for Best Visual Effects in 1980, recognizing his significant impact on the film industry. Brian Froud.search_query: When did Brian Froud become famous for his fantasy art?
Brian Froud.evidence:
Brian Froud gained significant recognition in the late 1970s for his contributions to fantasy art. In 1978, he co-authored and illustrated "Faeries" with Alan Lee, an illustrated compendium of faerie folklore. The book achieved international success, reaching number four on the New York Times Best Seller list and selling over five million copies by 2003. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brian_Froud?utm_source=openai))

His distinctive style and expertise in faerie lore caught the attention of filmmaker Jim Henson, leading to his role as the conceptual designer for the 1982 film "The Dark Crystal." Froud's collaboration with Henson continued with the 1986 film "Labyrinth," further solidifying his reputation in the fantasy art community. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brian_Froud?utm_source=openai))

These milestones in the late 1970s and early 1980s were pivotal in establishing Brian Froud as a prominent figure in the realm of fantasy art.

Alphonse Mucha.search_query: When did Alphonse Mucha become famous for Art Nouveau?
Alphonse Mucha.evidence:
Alphonse Mucha rose to prominence in the Art Nouveau movement in 1894 with his creation of a poster for actress Sarah Bernhardt's play "Gismonda." This work captivated audiences and marked a pivotal moment in his career. Bernhardt was so impressed that she signed him to an exclusive six-year contract, during which Mucha designed posters, sets, costumes, and even jewelry for her productions. ([artelino.com](https://www.artelino.com/articles/alphonse_mucha.asp?utm_source=openai))

Mucha's distinctive style, characterized by intricate patterns, flowing lines, and stylized depictions of women, became synonymous with Art Nouveau. His success with Bernhardt led to numerous commissions for advertisements, product designs, and decorative arts, solidifying his reputation as a leading figure in the movement. ([news.artnet.com](https://news.artnet.com/art-world/alphonse-mucha-art-nouveau-2616919?utm_source=openai))

Despite his association with Art Nouveau, Mucha was not fond of the term, believing that "art can never be new." He took the greatest pride in his work as a history painter. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alphonse_Mucha?utm_source=openai))

CSS Animations (@keyframes).search_query: When were CSS keyframe animations introduced?
CSS Animations (@keyframes).evidence:
CSS keyframe animations were introduced as part of the CSS3 specification, with the initial draft published by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) on March 20, 2009. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CSS_animations?utm_source=openai)) This module allows developers to animate HTML elements by defining keyframes that specify the styles at various points during the animation sequence.

Prior to this, animations on the web were typically achieved using JavaScript or Flash. The introduction of CSS keyframe animations provided a more efficient and standardized method for creating animations directly within CSS. This advancement has been widely adopted across modern web browsers, enabling smoother and more performant animations without the need for external plugins or scripts.

Initially, these implementations required vendor prefixes (e.g., `-webkit-`, `-moz-`, `-ms-`) to function correctly. Curling 'past decade' context (2010-2020.search_query: When would a 'past decade' of data starting in 2010 conclude?
Curling 'past decade' context (2010-2020.evidence:
A decade is a period of 10 years. If you're referring to a "past decade" starting in 2010, it would conclude on December 31, 2019. This is because, in the Gregorian calendar, decades are commonly defined as spanning from a year ending in '0' to a year ending in '9'. ([almanac.com](https://www.almanac.com/when-does-new-decade-start?utm_source=openai))

However, some argue that because there was no year zero in the Anno Domini system, the first decade began in year 1 and ended in year 10. By this reasoning, a decade starting in 2010 would end on December 31, 2020. ([withum.com](https://www.withum.com/resources/end-of-the-decade/?utm_source=openai))

In summary, while the most common convention is that a decade starting in 2010 ends on December 31, 2019, alternative interpretations based on the absence of a year zero suggest it could end on December 31, 2020.
